wordcram
Class Word

java.lang.Object
  wordcram.Word
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Comparable<Word>
public class Word
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<Word>

A weighted word, for rendering in the word cloud image.

Each Word object has a word String, and its associated weight, and it's constructed with these two things.

Hand-crafting Your Words

If you're creating your own Word[] to pass to the WordCram (rather than using something like WordCram.fromWebPage(String)), you can specify how a Word should be rendered: set a Word's font, size, etc: 
 Word w = new Word("texty", 20);
 w.setFont(createFont("myFontName", 1));
 w.setAngle(radians(45));
Any values set on a Word will override the corresponding component (WordColorer, WordAngler, etc) - it won't even be called for that word.

Word Properties

A word can also have properties. If you're creating custom components, you might want to send other information along with the word, for the components to use: 
 Word strawberry = new Word("strawberry", 10);
 strawberry.setProperty("isFruit", true);

 Word pea = new Word("pea", 10);
 pea.setProperty("isFruit", false);

 new WordCram(this)
   .fromWords(new Word[] { strawberry, pea })
   .withColorer(new WordColorer() {
      public int colorFor(Word w) {
        if (w.getProperty("isFruit") == true) {
          return color(255, 0, 0);
        }
        else {
          return color(0, 200, 0);
        }
      }
    });

getTargetPlace

public processing.core.PVector getTargetPlace()
Get the place the Word was supposed to be rendered at: either the value passed to setPlace(), or the value returned from the WordPlacer.

getRenderedPlace

public processing.core.PVector getRenderedPlace()
Get the final place the Word was rendered at, or null if it couldn't be placed. It returns the original target location (which is either the value passed to setPlace(), or the value returned from the WordPlacer), plus the nudge vector returned by the WordNudger.

Returns:
If word was placed, it's the (x,y) coordinates of the word's final location; else it's null.

wasPlaced

public boolean wasPlaced()
Indicates whether the Word was placed successfully. It's the same as calling word.getRenderedPlace() != null. If this returns false, it's either because a) WordCram didn't get to this Word yet, or b) it was skipped for some reason (see wasSkipped() and wasSkippedBecause()).

Returns:
true only if the word was placed.

wasSkipped

public boolean wasSkipped()
Indicates whether the Word was skipped.

Returns:
true if the word was skipped
See Also:
wasSkippedBecause()

wasSkippedBecause

public java.lang.Integer wasSkippedBecause()
Tells you why this Word was skipped. If the word was skipped, then this will return an Integer, which will be one of WordCram.WAS_OVER_MAX_NUMBER_OF_WORDS, WordCram.SHAPE_WAS_TOO_SMALL, or WordCram.NO_SPACE. If the word was successfully placed, or WordCram hasn't gotten to this word yet, this will return null.

Returns:
the code for the reason the word was skipped, or null if it wasn't skipped.

getProperty

public java.lang.Object getProperty(java.lang.String propertyName)
Get a property value from this Word, for a WordColorer, a WordPlacer, etc.

propertyName -
Returns:

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Displays the word, and its weight (in parentheses). new Word("hello", 1.3).toString() will return "hello (0.3)".

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

compareTo

public int compareTo(Word w)
Compares Words based on weight only. Words with equal weight are arbitrarily sorted.

Specified by:
compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Word>
